facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1 and 2 of 1949 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1 and 2 of 1949. Appeals from the Judgment and Decree dated the 22nd December, 1942,

facts.text: Appeals from Judgment and Decree dated 22nd December 1942 of High Court of Patna in First Appeals Nos. 10 and 11 of 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the Judgment and Decree dated the 22nd December, 1942, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in First Appeals Nos. 10 and 1 1 of 1939 arising out of the Judgment and Decree dated the 23rd

facts.text: Original Suit No. 11 of 1935 decided by Subordinate Judge of Berhampore on 23rd November 1936.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Judgment and Decree dated the 23rd November, 1936, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Berhampore in Original Suit No. 11 of 1935. V. Narasinga Rao and M. S. K. Sastri for the appellant.

facts.text: Suit instituted by respondents to enforce mortgage deed Exhibit A dated 5th April 1923 executed by defendant in favour of Radha Prasad Bhagat.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-These appeals arise out of a suit instituted by the respondents to enforce a mortgage deed, Exhibit A, dated 5th April, 1923, executed by the defendant in favour of one Radha Prasad Bhagat.

facts.text: Mortgage subject-matter is Bodogodo Zemindari situated in District of Ganjam in Province of Madras, comprised in State of Orissa, governed by Madras Impartible Estates Act 11 of 1904.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of the mortgage is an estate called the Bodogodo Zemin situated in what was the District of Ganjam in the Province of Madras and number companyprised in the State of Orissa, and governed by the provisions of the Madras Impartible Estates Act 11 of 1904.

facts.text: Mortgage for Rs. 1,25,000: Rs. 12,500 advanced on promissory note dated 30th March 1923, balance Rs. 1,12,500 paid in cash.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage is for Rs. 1,25,000 and the deed recites that a sum of Rs. 12,500 was advanced to the mortgagor on a promissory numbere executed on 30th March, 1923, that the balance of Rs. 1,12,500 was paid to him in cash,

facts.text: Amount borrowed for expenses of marriage of defendant's second daughter with eldest son of Rajah of Talcher, marriage took place on 27th April 1923.

anchor.surface_text: and that the entire amount was borrowed for meeting the expenses of the marriage of his second daughter with the eldest son of the Rajah of Talcher. The marriage, in fact, took place on 27th April, 1923.

facts.text: Plaintiffs case: Rs. 1,12,500 paid on 14th April 1923 to defendant's manager Mr. Henry Tapp after mortgage registered on 10th April 1923.

anchor.surface_text: Though the deed recites that Rs. 1, 12,500 was paid in cash, the case of the plaintiffs is that it was, in fact, paid on 14th April, 1923, on the authority of the defendant to his manager, one Mr. Henry Tapp, after the mortgage bond was registered, which was on 10th April, 1923.

facts.text: Defendant made payments towards mortgage in 1926 and 1927 aggregating Rs. 42,000.

anchor.surface_text: In 1926 and 1927 the defendant made several payments towards the mortgage, in all aggregating to Rs. 42,000. The mortgagee died on 18th November, 1933,

facts.text: Mortgagee Radha Prasad Bhagat died on 18th November 1933.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagee died on 18th November, 1933, and thereafter his legal representatives filed the suit, out of which these appeals arise, for recovery of the balance due under the mortgage by sale of the hypothecated property.

facts.text: Defendant pleaded mortgage supported by consideration only to extent of Rs. 25,000 and discharged by payments in 1926-1927; not duly attested or validly registered.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant resisted the suit on several grounds. He pleaded that the mortgage was supported by companysideration only to the extent of Rs. 25,000, and that it had become discharged by the payments made in 1926 and 1927. He also companytended that the mortgage bond was number duly attested or validly, registered, and that it was therefore void and unenforceable.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held no consideration for promissory note Exhibit J dated 30th March 1923 (salami), but Rs. 1,12,500 paid to Tapp under authority; bond duly attested and registered; passed decree.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge of Berhampur who heard the suit held that numberconsideration passed for the promissory numbere for Rs. 12,500 dated 30th March, 1923, Exhibit J, and that it was really a salami but that the balance of Rs. 1, 1 2,500 was paid to Mr. Tapp under the authority of the defendant. He also held that the mortgage bond was duly attested and validly registered, and a decree was passed in accordance with these findings

facts.text: Plaintiffs filed A.S. No. 10 of 1937 in High Court claiming consideration for Exhibit J.

anchor.surface_text: Both the parties took up the matter in appeal to the High Court of Patna. The plaintiffs filed A. S. No. 10 of 1937 claiming that Exhibit J was supported by companysideration, and the defendant filed A. S. No. 11 of 1937

facts.text: Defendant filed A.S. No. 11 of 1937 claiming payment to Tapp unauthorised and bond void for lack of attestation/registration.

anchor.surface_text: pleading that the alleged payment of Rs. 1,12,500 to Mr. Tapp was unauthorised, and that the mortgage bond was void, as it was neither duly attested number properly registered. The High Court companycurred with the Subordinate Judge

facts.text: High Court concurred with Subordinate Judge that Rs. 1,12,500 paid to Tapp under authority and bond duly attested/registered; held Exhibit J supported by consideration.

anchor.surface_text: in finding that Rs. 1,12,500 was paid to Mr. Tapp under the authority of the defendant, and that the bond was duly attested and registered. But as regards the promissory numbere, Exhibit J, it held differing from the Subordinate Judge that it was also supported by companysideration.

facts.text: Mortgage deed Exhibit A presented for registration by Mr. Tapp as agent under power-of-attorney Exhibit B.

anchor.surface_text: In-the. present case, Exhibit A was presented for registration by Mr. Tapp as the agent of the defendant under a power-of-attorney executed by him, Exhibit B, and the question is whether that power satisfies the requirements of section 33.

facts.text: Power-of-attorney Exhibit B executed by defendant before Registrar at residence of Chief of Hindol at Cuttack and authenticated by him.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit B was executed by the defendant before the Registrar at the residence of the Chief of Hindol at Cuttack and was authenticated by him. It was argued for the appellant that the authentication was invalid on three grounds

facts.text: Courts below found defendant residing at Cuttack for a week prior to execution of Exhibit B.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the first companytention that the defendant was number residing at Cuttack at the date of Exhibit B, and companysequently the Registrar of that place had numberjurisdiction to register it under section 33  1   a , the finding of the companyrts below is that the defendant had been residing at Cuttack for a week prior to the date of Exhibit B,

facts.text: Supreme Court affirmed finding that defendant was residing at Cuttack at time of Exhibit B.

anchor.surface_text: Under the circumstances there were ample materials to support the finding of the companyrts below that the appellant was residing at Cuttack at the time of Exhibit B, and that must be affirmed.

facts.text: Defendant died while appeals pending; legal representatives prosecuting.

anchor.surface_text: As for companyts, it must be mentioned that the defendant died while the appeals were pending, and that it is his legal  1   1929  56 I.A. 379.  2   1901 28 I.A. 15. representatives who are prosecuting them.

facts.text: Trial court found mortgage not binding on estate under section 4 of Madras Impartible Estates Act; High Court discharged the finding leaving question open.

anchor.surface_text: The property mortgaged is an estate governed by the Madras impartable Estates Act 11 of 1904. The plaintiffs alleged in their plaint that the mortgage was binding on the estate under section 4 of the Act. Issue 6 was framed with reference to this allegation, and the finding of the trial companyrt was that it was number binding on the estate. But on appeal, the High Court held that the question companyld number be gone into in a suit laid against the mortgagor. It accordingly discharged the finding,

holdings.text: The mortgage deed was validly registered in accordance with sections 32 and 33 of the Registration Act.

holdings.text: Power-of-attorney Exhibit B satisfies the requirements of section 33.

anchor.surface_text: In-the. present case, Exhibit A was presented for registration by Mr. Tapp as the agent of the defendant under a power-of-attorney executed by him, Exhibit B, and the question is whether that power satisfies the requirements of section 33.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authentication valid on all grounds examined; presentation by agent proper under section 33.

holdings.text: The defendant was residing at Cuttack at the time of execution of Exhibit B sufficient to confer jurisdiction on Registrar under section 33(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: Under the circumstances there were ample materials to support the finding of the courts below that the appellant was residing at Cuttack at the time of Exhibit B, and that must be affirmed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary residence sufficient per Privy Council precedent in Sharat Chandra Basu; facts support lower courts' finding including endorsement and circumstances.

holdings.text: Exhibit B was presented for authentication, not registration; section 32 inapplicable; erroneous endorsement ignored.

precedents.citation: Jambu Prasad v. Muhammad Aftar Ali Khan 1

anchor.surface_text: In Jambu Prasad v. Muhammad Aftar Ali Khan 1 , it was observed by the Judicial Committee approving of the decision in Ishri Prasad v. Baijnath 2  that, the terms of sections 32 and 33 of Act III of 1877 are imperative, and that a presentation of a document for registration by an agent who has number been duly authorized in accordance

precedents.case_name: Jambu Prasad v. Muhammad Aftar Ali Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: terms of sections 32 and 33 of Act III of 1877 are imperative, and presentation of a document for registration by an agent who has not been duly authorized does not give the Registering Officer authority to register the document

anchor.surface_text: In Jambu Prasad v. Muhammad Aftar Ali Khan 1 , it was observed by the Judicial Committee approving of the decision in Ishri Prasad v. Baijnath 2  that, the terms of sections 32 and 33 of Act III of 1877 are imperative, and that a presentation of a document for registration by an agent who has number been duly authorized in accordance

precedents.cited_proposition: terms of sections 32 and 33 of Act III of 1877 are imperative

precedents.citation: Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab 1

anchor.surface_text: In Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab 1  the Privy Council observed The expression resides, as used in section 33, is number defined in the statute but there is numberreason for assuming that it companytemplates only permanent residence and excludes temporary residence.

precedents.case_name: Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab
precedents.cited_proposition: expression 'resides' as used in section 33 includes temporary residence
precedents.cited_holding: The expression resides, as used in section 33, is not defined in the statute but there is no reason for assuming that it contemplates only permanent residence and excludes temporary residence

precedents.citation: Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab 1

anchor.surface_text: In Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab 1  the endorsement on the power-of-attorney was as follows  1  64 I.A. 77 Executed in my presence at the Hazaribagh Registration Office on August 8, 1916, by Sharat Chandra Basu, son of Nalinaksha Basu of Burd wan, at present of Hazaribagh

precedents.case_name: Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab
precedents.cited_proposition: endorsement on power-of-attorney is evidence of residence of the principal
precedents.cited_holding: the endorsement of the Sub-Registrar on the document expressly states that he was living, at that time, at Hazaribagh

precedents.citation: Bharat Indu v. Hamid Ali Khan 1

anchor.surface_text: In Bharat Indu v. Hamid Ali Khan 1 , apower-of-attorney executed by a mortgagor was presented for registration by his servant but actually the Registrar registered it at the residence of the principal under section 33. In a suit to enforce the mortgage, the contention was raised that the registration of the mortgage deed was bad, as the power-of- attorney in pursuance of which it was registered was presented for registration by a person number authorised.

precedents.case_name: Bharat Indu v. Hamid Ali Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: even if initial presentation of power-of-attorney for registration is bad, subsequent authentication/registration at residence of principal under section 33 validates it
precedents.cited_holding: when it was subsequently registered at the residence of the executant in accordance with section 33 it should be deemed to have been presented by him to the Registrar, and that in that view the registration would be valid

precedents.citation: Ma Pwa May v. Chettiar Firm 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ma Pwa May v. Chettiar Firm 1  Lord Atkin observed In seeking to apply this section  section 87 , it is important to distinguish between defects in the procedure of the Registrar and lack of jurisdiction. Where the Registrar has numberjurisdiction to register, as where a person number entitled to do so presents for registration, or where there is lack of territorial jurisdiction, or where the presentation is out of time, the section is inoperative

precedents.case_name: Ma Pwa May v. Chettiar Firm
precedents.cited_proposition: distinguish between defects in procedure of Registrar and lack of jurisdiction; mistake in exercise of jurisdiction does not invalidate under section 87 (now 49?)
precedents.cited_holding: if the registrar having a jurisdiction has made a mistake in the exercise of it, the section takes effect

anchor.surface_text: Where the Registrar has numberjurisdiction to register, as where a person number entitled to do so presents for registration, or where there is lack of territorial jurisdiction, or where the presentation is out of time, the section is inoperative see Mujibunnissa v. Abdul Rahim 2 . On the other hand, if the registrar having a jurisdiction has made a mistake in the exercise of it, the section  section 33  takes effect.

precedents.cited_proposition: cases where Registrar has no jurisdiction, registration inoperative

justification_sets.label: Procedural Defect vs Lack of Jurisdiction in Registration support
